qas.question: How are the sender and receiver connected in a slightly more complex form of communication model?
What is the model of communication in which the sender and receiver are connected reciprocally called?
What is something that may alter the intended meaning of a message?
What is something that may cause the reception and decoding of the content of a message to be faulty?
Code books are represented in what?

plausible_answers.text: the constitutive model or constructionist view

qas.question: The first attitude of communication is referred to as what?
Occasionally instances of communication are called what?
A sender or receiver's what never varies regardless of culture or gender?
A person's age may change a sender or receiver's what?

context: In a slightly more complex form a sender and a receiver are linked <a0_0>reciprocally<a0_0/>. This second attitude of communication, referred to as <b6_0>the <a1_0>constitutive model or constructionist view<b6_0/><a1_0/>, focuses on how an individual communicates as the determining factor of the way the message will be interpreted. Communication is viewed as <a2_0>a conduit<a2_0/>; a passage in which information travels from one individual to another and this information becomes separate from the communication itself. A particular instance of communication is called <b7_0>a speech act<b7_0/>. The sender's <b8_0><b9_0>personal filters<b9_0/><b8_0/> and the receiver's personal filters may vary depending upon <a3_0>different regional traditions<a3_0/>, cultures, or gender; which may alter the intended meaning of message contents. In the presence of "<a4_0>communication noise<a4_0/>" on the transmission channel (air, in this case), reception and decoding of content may be faulty, and thus the speech act may not achieve the desired effect. One problem with this encode-transmit-receive-decode model is that the processes of encoding and decoding imply that the sender and receiver each possess something that functions as a codebook, and that these two code books are, at the very least, similar if not identical. Although something like code books is implied by the model, they are nowhere represented in <b5_0>the model<b5_0/>, which creates many conceptual difficulties.
